question: Are gender quotas in the EU advantageous for the economies of member states?

content.source_1: European Commission (2022). Directive (EU) 2022/2381 on improving gender balance among directors of listed companies, and accompanying analyses. The Commission argues that mandated targets can correct persistent market failures in board selection, improving governance quality, decision-making, innovation, and long-run firm performance; it links greater gender balance to better resource allocation and, via higher female participation and leadership, to positive EU-wide growth effects. (eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/dir/2022/2381/oj)
content.source_2: Ahern, K. R., & Dittmar, A. K. (2012). The Changing of the Boards: The Impact on Firm Valuation of Mandated Female Board Representation. Quarterly Journal of Economics. Using Norway’s quota as a natural experiment, they find a short-run decline in firm value and a shift to younger, less experienced boards, suggesting potential economic costs from abrupt quota-induced board changes. (academic.oup.com/qje/article/127/1/137/1907557)
content.source_3: Matsa, D. A., & Miller, A. R. (2013). A Female Style in Corporate Leadership? Evidence from Quotas. American Economic Journal: Applied Economics. Also studying Norway, they find quota-affected firms reduced layoffs and maintained employment through downturns, trading off lower short-term profits for greater employment stability—an effect that can have macroeconomic benefits during recessions. (aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/app.5.3.136)
content.source_4: Bertrand, M., Black, S., Jensen, S., & Lleras-Muney, A. (2019). Breaking the Glass Ceiling? The Effect of Board Quotas on Female Labor Market Outcomes in Norway. Review of Economic Studies. They document substantial increases in female directors but limited spillovers to broader female labor-market outcomes (wages/employment), implying quotas alone may yield modest aggregate economic gains. (academic.oup.com/restud/article/86/1/191/5073799)
content.source_5: Bøhren, Ø., & Staubo, Ø. (2014). Does mandatory gender balance work? Changing organizational form to avoid board upheaval. Journal of Corporate Finance. Evidence that some Norwegian firms avoided the quota by delisting or changing legal form, potentially reducing public-market depth and investment—an economy-level cost from rigid mandates. (sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S092911991400050X)
content.source_6: International Monetary Fund (2018). Women in Finance: A Case for Closing Gaps (Sahay, Čihák, et al.). Cross-country evidence (including EU banks) associates more women on bank boards and in leadership with greater financial stability (e.g., higher capital buffers, lower NPLs), suggesting potential macroeconomic advantages to policies—quotas among them—that raise female representation. (imf.org/en/Publications/Staff-Discussion-Notes/Issues/2018/09/17/Women-in-Finance-A-Case-for-Closing-Gaps-45543)
